awd_abstract_narration:
****Nontechnical abstract****
Nature acts as an exquisite engineer capable of creating structures and functionalities that are unmatched by anything manmade, such as the rupture-free passage of a virus through a cellular membrane, the ability of a highly motile white blood cells to seek and destroy an immunogenic target, or synchronously beating ciliary fields clearing debris from a lung. This research team draws inspiration from such biological capabilities. They seek to uncover the fundamental design principles underlying these and other remarkable biological functions, and to use this knowledge to create a new generation of biomaterials that are endowed with properties heretofore found only in living organisms. The research straddles the interface between biology and materials science. Starting from a few well-characterized building blocks of biochemical origin, they are building structures of increasing complexity to determine which components are required for the emergence of desired biological functionality. The project runs a multi-level outreach and education program, structured around a set of key activities: exhibits at the Discovery Museums of Acton, MA, field trips for high school students, a summer Research Experience for Undergraduates, minority mentoring program in conjunction with the Science Posse of New York, summer courses in advanced experimental techniques based on the project's shared facilities and provides career development opportunities for graduate students and post-doctoral fellows. 

****Technical abstract****
This project seeks to create new materials that are constructed from only a few simplified components, yet capture the remarkable functionalities found in living organisms.  In addition to opening new directions in materials science research, these efforts serve to elucidate the minimal requirements for the emergence of biological function. This challenging endeavor draws on expertise in diverse and complementary experimental and theoretical techniques that span the physical and life sciences. This group of individuals are collaborating to combine elemental building blocks, such as motor proteins, DNA origami and filamentous virus, to understand the emergence of biomimetic functionalities that are highly sought-after in materials science and to synergistically engineer life-like materials. The goal of their first project, Membrane based Materials, is to uncover the design principles that cells use to shape and reconfigure membranes, and to apply these principles in order to engineer heterogeneous and reconfigurable membrane materials. To accomplish this they are exploiting the analogy between nanometer-sized lipid bilayers and micron-sized colloidal monolayers assembled from filamentous viruses or DNA origami rods. The goal of their second project, Biological Active Materials, is to create active analogs of quintessential soft matter systems including gels, liquids crystals, emulsions and vesicles using elemental force generators, such as motor proteins and monomer treadmilling. They are experimentally and theoretically characterizing the emergent properties of such materials, including their ability to convert chemical energy into mechanical work, perform locomotion, and undergo dynamical reconfiguration.

por.por_cntn:
The Brandeis MRSEC, Bioinspired Soft Materials, comprises two IRGs, IRG1: Membrane based Materials and IRG2: Biological Active Materials.

The goal of IRG1: Membrane based Materials was to uncover the design principles that cells use to shape and reconfigure membranes, and to apply these principles to engineer heterogeneous and reconfigurable membrane materials. To accomplish this, MRSEC investigators exploited the analogy between nanometer-sized lipid bilayers and micron-sized colloidal monolayers assembled from filamentous viruses or DNA origami rods. A grand challenge facing lipid membrane science is understanding how compartmentalization occurs in the liquid lipid membrane. The current paradigm is that lipids microphase separate into rafts with diameters ranging from 10 – 1000 nm, and that proteins preferentially partition into rafts of a particular composition. However, direct visualization of rafts in living cells remains elusive. In contrast, IRG1 studied colloidal raft properties by direct imaging using optical microscopy, and developed both theoretical and computational models that were validated by experiment.

One striking highlight was raft formation in monolayers of rods bidisperse in length. This work involved theorists working with experimentalists who showed that both chirality and rod length affect packing entropy, leading to unexpected consequences for the material properties of the membrane. The results depended only on the excluded volume, or shape entropy of the molecules. Consequently, these phenomena are universal and will hold equally for nanoscale lipid membranes and micron-scale colloidal membranes. MRSEC investigators speculate that these effects could contribute to the existence of lipid rafts in lipid membranes, an important and controversial subject in biophysics. Because the theory is universal, these engineering principles can be used to build functional heterogeneous membranes. None of these results could have been achieved by individual investigators working in isolation; rather, they required a synergistic union of theoretical and experimental researchers from the physical and life sciences working together and using the shared facilities and expertise made available by the Brandeis MRSEC.

The goal of IRG2: Biological Active Materials was to build active soft materials driven far-from-equilibrium by chemical-consuming molecular motors, to produce self-sustained complex emergent dynamics.  The central achievements of this IRG include truly macroscopic experiments on long-lived active materials and elucidating the role of confinement in reshaping active matter dynamics.

In one highlight,  experiments on macroscopic samples were combined with theory and simulations to characterize the structure and dynamics of 2D active liquid crystals. This led to the discovery of the unexpected emergent orientational ordering of motile and transient defects and characterization of vortex distributions in the flows. Their work has instigated a major research effort in soft condensed matter physics, as the universal dynamics identified in this system applies to all two-dimensional anisotropic active fluids. It has also served as a paradigm for integrating experiments with theory and simulation to understand dynamical phenomena in active matter.  

MRSEC investigators also showed that confining walls self-organize the dynamics of active nematics giving rise to coherent and periodic dynamics. The role of confinement is even more dramatic in the case of a 3D active fluid, where they identified a class of confinements that transform the chaotic dynamics of 3D active isotropic fluids into long-ranged coherent flows that persist on a meter lengthscale.
